overall_score_comment: A solid 4 out of 10: the musical equivalent of bubble wrap – provides temporary anxiety relief but ultimately just repetitive popping.
the_roast:
Benson Boone has discovered anxiety and decided to make it everyone's problem through the medium of song. 'For a while there, it was rough / But lately, I've been doin' better / Than the last four cold Decembers I recall' – my guy is out here treating mental health like a Yelp review: 'Three stars, would recommend over previous Decembers, but still waiting on fries.' The specificity of FOUR Decembers is sending me. Not three, not five – specifically four cold ones. Were the other months fine? Did September treat you right?

The entire premise is 'I finally got my life together and now I'm terrified it'll disappear,' which, fair enough, but he's delivered it with all the theological nuance of a guy who just discovered Pascal's Wager at a coffee shop. 'I thank God every day for the girl He sent my way / But I know the things He gives me, He can take away' – this isn't romance, it's a hostage negotiation with the Almighty. Nothing says 'I love you' quite like 'God could smite this relationship at any moment, so let's cuddle!' His girlfriend must feel SO secure knowing she's essentially a divine loaner car that could get repossessed at any moment.

Then we arrive at the chorus, which I can only describe as aggressive begging set to music. 'Please stay / I want you, I need you, oh God / Don't take / These beautiful things that I've got' repeats so many times that Spotify should classify this as a prayer, not a pop song. The man has condensed his entire emotional spectrum into four phrases and decided to just… loop them. It's like he's holding the universe at metaphorical gunpoint going 'PLEASE DON'T TAKE MY STUFF' over and over. And that bridge? 'If everything's good and it's great, why do I sit and wait 'til it's gone?' – Congratulations, Benson, you've discovered anticipatory anxiety. The Psychology 101 department called, they want their breakthrough back.

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I see my family every month
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Setting the bar for emotional stability at once-monthly family visits
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory attendance at weekly family dinners until you understand that's literally the minimum

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: She'll come and stay the night, and I think I might have it all
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Defining 'having it all' as someone occasionally sleeping over
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to read every self-help book until expectations are appropriately calibrated

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: But there's no man as terrified as the man who stands to lose you
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Making anxiety sound like a competitive sport
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Sentenced to therapy and a prescription for whatever makes you chill out about basic human connection

lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Using 'oh, ooh' as if it constitutes actual lyrical content
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Forty hours of community service writing complete sentences with verbs and everything

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: If everything's good and it's great, why do I sit and wait 'til it's gone?
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Asking rhetorical questions that every therapist could answer in one session
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory enrollment in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and a ban on philosophical pondering in verse form

hidden_meanings: This is clearly an allegory about supply chain anxiety in late-stage capitalism. The 'beautiful things' represent consumer goods, and Benson is terrified that Amazon will run out of two-day shipping. 'Please stay' is actually him begging his Prime membership not to expire, and the girlfriend is obviously a metaphor for his credit score. Deep stuff.
final_verdict: Benson Boone has written the musical equivalent of wrapping yourself in bubble wrap because you're afraid of bumping into furniture. It's a catchy plea for the universe to please not repo his happiness, delivered with the emotional maturity of someone who just discovered feelings have names.
title: Beautiful Things
